title: Burnham urges Harman to drop her call for Labour to abstain on welfare bill - Politics live | Politics | The Guardian
summary: andy burnham 's press gallery hustings - summary and verdict .
burnham says labour should vote against the welfare bill as it stands .
cameron appears to rule out beefing up evel plans in light of snp 's hunting stance .
sturgeon defends snp 's u-turn decision on hunting vote .

documents.title: afternoon summary
text: andy burnham , the favourite in the labour leadership contest , has confirmed that he is opposed to harriet harman 's call for the party to abstain in next week 's vote on the welfare bill .
he also refused to rule out defying the whip and voting against the bill if labour mps are told to abstain .
( see 4.06pm . )
the government has withdrawn its attempt to relax the uk 's foxhunting ban after the scottish national party said it would vote against the change .

an interest rate hike in the uk is moving closer '' , the governor of the bank of england told mps in comments that have fanned market expectations that policymakers could start to tighten borrowing costs before the end of the year .
theresa may , the home secretary , has told mps that a secure zone is to be set up in calais to protect lorries from migrants trying to climb on board to enter britain illegally .
david cameron has ruled out british taxpayers providing any funding for a greek bailout , despite speculation the uk could be asked to contribute as much as £ 1bn towards the bill .
cameron has accused critics of a huge trade deal with the us of inventing false scare stories that we will all be force-fed chlorinated chickens '' in a bid to scupper the crucial '' agreement .

as the press association reports , urging business chiefs to help make the case , he conceded that the agreement faced a big fight '' to overcome sustained attacks from left-wing opponents and warned britain would rue the day if we miss this opportunity '' to open up transatlantic markets .

speaking at the times ceo summit , he said : i am hugely positive about it but i think we have a big fight to win because the left across europe is mobilising , often through ngos , to try to find all sorts of reasons why this is a bad idea .
but when you examine them - whether it is the idea we are all going to be force-fed chlorinated chickens or have american banks buy up our health service - they all fall apart .

there is no question : the national health service will remain a national heath service and in terms of these investor dispute resolution mechanisms , we have signed them into all the trade deals we 've ever done and we 've never lost a single case .
so a lot of the arguments against ttip do fall apart but we need to challenge them almost before they come out and i think business can really help with this .
that 's all from me for today .
thanks for the comments .

documents.title: andy burnham 's press gallery hustings - summary and verdict
text: andy burnham is the third of the labour leadership candidates to address a press gallery hustings .
liz kendall probably made the best impression , in that she was relatively unknown when she spoke in may , and she attracted some rave reviews .
yvette cooper spoke last month , and she came over as serious and experienced , if not exactly exciting .
burnham is still the favourite in the contest , but today he seemed to playing for a no-score draw ( which is probably what he achieved ) .
his opening speech gave us a news line about the welfare bill , but otherwise it was unremarkable .
his ardent labourphilia , which works will when he deploys it at normal hustings event , was never going go to down well with a room full of journalists , and wisely he did n't try it today .

the questions were n't especially hostile , but burnham has received some grotesquely negative coverage in the sun ( they seem to be waging a vendetta against him over hillsborough ) , and he was non-committal when asked if he would give them an interview .
he did not say anything brilliant or inspiring , but he did not say anything crass or naive either .
at coffee house isabel hardman has written up his peformance as solid '' ; that feels about right .
here are the key points .
burnham said that labour should vote against the welfare bill .

specifically , he said that the party should tabled a reasoned amendment , explaining what it disliked about the bill , and then only vote against if the reasoned amendment fails ( but that amounts to the same thing , because a reasoned amendment is one saying why a bill should not get a second reading ) .
explaining his opposition to the bill , he said : the welfare reform and work bill is unsupportable because it does n't do what it says on the tin - support work .
in fact , it does the opposite .
it diminishes work incentives with its changes to tax credits and the esa .
it does n't encourage people into work .
it fact it might do the opposite .
it contains some punitive measures in respect of child poverty .
if you ask the public about welfare reform , they would be in favour of welfare reform , as i am - i am in favour of welfare reform .
but they would say 'create more incentives to work and do n't punish children or those who ca n't work ' .
the bill abolishes the measurements around child poverty and at the same time has measures that will push children into poverty .
that seems to me to make it a very duplicitous bill .
harriet harman , the acting labour leader , wants the party to abstain when mps debate the bill next week .
burnham said that he set out his views on what the party should do when the shadow cabinet met this morning .
a final decision as to how labour tells its mps to vote will be taken nearer the time .
burnham did not rule out defying the whip and voting against if labour mps are told to abstain , but he suggested this was unlikely .
this is what he said when asked about it .

i will make my decisions at the point where the party has its agreed position , but as you will know i am somebody who supports the collective line of the party , and i 've made my views in the proper way in shadow cabinet .
i am not normally somebody who then goes outside of the collective ways of agreeing things , but , you know , i 've made my position very clear in terms of what i expect to see .
he implied that tony blair 's reluctance to offend news international helped to explain why he did not order a full inquiry into hillsborough .

he said : i said i would not get back into a situation where the labour party , and the leader of the labour party , is going on bended knee to certain newspapers , trying to court newspapers , because i think in the end that gets you into difficulty .
and it got us to the point where a whole city was crying injustice throughout our time in government and we were n't listening .

asked if he was saying that a hillsborough inquiry would have taken place sooner if it had not been for labour 's relationship with newspapers , he replied : i am saying that it seems there was a decision to leave it alone .

i do n't know all of the background to the decision-making , but in 1998 , after the stuart-smith inquiry , a decision was taken to draw a line under it and to leave it in that position , [ i was told ] i was better not to carry on looking into it .
that was the wrong decision .
he said labour might drop its support for hs2 if he became leader .
he said he had not yet taken a final view on hs2 , but that he thought east/west transport links were more of a priority than north/south ones .
i believe a higher priority for public investment are east/west transport links across our country i 'm also talking about transport links to the south west .
this country does n't work well east/west , and in my view the higher priority is to improve those links , rather than north/south links .
he hinted that he might appoint a woman as shadow chancellor .
he would appoint a woman to shadow the first secretary of state post , he said , and he suggested that person could also be shadow chancellor .
that makes rachel reeves a favourite for the job if he becomes leader .
he said george osborne was devolving power in england in entirely the wrong way '' .
he was devolving a funding crisis '' , burnham said .
he said the government should devolve from the bottom up , by giving more power to councils .
update : stig abell , the sun 's managing editor , has been in touch .
stig abell ( @ stigabell ) @ andrewsparrow `` they seem to be waging a vendetta against him over hillsborough '' what utter nonsense .
we think he 's a hypocrite and said so .
andrewsparrow ( @ andrewsparrow ) @ stigabell thanks .
have you got a link to the piece that explains that ?
stig abell ( @ stigabell ) @ andrewsparrow i 'm sure you could find plenty of you wanted : i 'm grateful for the links .
if you read them , i think you 'll find they illustrate my point .

they certainly show that the sun 's burnham coverage has been excessively pejorative , although if abell says this has nothing to do with hillsborough , not being privy to the inner thoughts of sun hq , i suppose i 'll have to take his word for that .
update at 6pm : a sun source has been in touch to explain why he thinks i 'm wrong to suggest that the sun is pursuing a vendetta against burnham over hillsborough .

he asks , quite reasonably : what on earth have we to gain by trying to defend our terrible hillsborough blunder now , when we 've already apologised for it five times and are as supportive as anyone now of the new inquest and investigation ? ''
he also points out that the paper fully supports the new inquest .
but hillsborough clearly is a factor in the mix .

the paper is quite open about the fact that it is criticising burnham because he wo n't speak to it - see above - although the source claimed that that was not the only reason for the negative coverage , and that burnham 's politics came into it too .
and it 's hillsborough that explains why burnham does n't speak to the paper , according to a source in his camp .
the stand-off seems to have become self-reinforcing .
as the sun 's coverage has got more critical , burnham seems to have become even more reluctant to engage with it - thereby fuelling its anger .
so there is a vendetta , of sorts .
and it is hillsborough-related .
but it is not a straightforward matter of the sun simply pillorying burnham in retaliation for his hillsborough campaigning .
q : would you back the extension of air strikes against islamic state to syria ?
burnham says he would proceed cautiously '' but responsibly '' .
in 2013 he advised ed miliband to proceed cautiously '' .
he was worried about the parallels with iraq .
he says the publication of the chilcot report will be a sobering moment for labour .
the lessons it contains should inform future labour foreign policy , he says .
and that 's it .
i 'll post a summary soon .
q : should trade unions accept whatever the law says ?
burnhams says everyone should live within the law .
that goes without saying .
but this bill is highly unjustified .
what justification is there for saying trade unions require a higher threshold than applies for ballots in other areas of public life .
q : how much damage to you think the opt in '' plans for union political funds will cause ?
he says he decided not to take trade union money because he wanted to show his independence .
he thinks trade union money is the cleanest in politics .
he says these plans are designed to hurt labour .
not having taken union money , he will be in a stronger position to stand up for unions , he says .
q : if you lose , will you ask for your old job back ?
burnham says he is confident he will be the next leader of the labour party .
he is not thinking of anything else at the moment .
labour will look , sound and feel very different from what it has been '' under his leadership , he says .
q : what would you do about free schools ?
burnham says he does not support the free-for-all approach .
he would want free schools to be brought back into a local family of schools .
you do not have to have losers for their to be winners .
he says he does not think the forced academisation of schools is a good thing .
q : who would you have as shadow chancellor ?
burnham says he has said he favours balance .
he would appoint a woman was shadow first secretary of state .
that person could be shadow chancellor .
( so that sounds like it would be rachel reeves . )
q : what is your alternative to the northern powerhouse ?
burnham says george osborne is going about this the wrong way .
he wants one mayor of the north east of england .
that wo n't necessarily work .
true devolution should come from the bottom up , he says .
he says local government should have a single budget at local level .
there should no longer be silos for spending , he says .
and councils should have more power over education , over the high street , and over issues like fracking .
the body politic has been decaying from the bottom up .
councils do not have enough power , he says .
osborne is going entirely the wrong way about it '' , he says .
he is devolving a funding crisis '' .
q : would you rebel if the party says mps should abstain on the welfare bill ?
burnham says he will take a decision nearer the time .
but he is someone who normally supports collective decisions .
q : what cuts would you implement if you were in government ?
burnham says he was chief secretary to the treasury at the time of the last spending review .
they imposed real-terms cuts on departments .
he says he is not in principle opposed to a benefit cap .
but it depends how it is done , he says .
he would not have cut inheritance tax .
he will reserve judgment on the freeze to working-age benefits .
but he would like to see some evidence as to whether or not that will be a disincentive to work .
on housing benefit , the cap [ the benefits cap ] is designed to imply people are getting £ 23,000 in their hands .
they are not .
that is going to landlords , some of whom do not put money into their property .
q : should be budget by balanced by 2019 ?
burnham says we should be working towards a surplus in good times .
q : what would you say about grexit if you were prime minister today ?
burnham says the eu is becoming associated with a rightwing orthodoxy .
he is worried about a loss of support for the eu .
we wo n't be able to win a referendum if people see it as a race to the bottom ?
q : who do you think was responsible for labour not wanting to pursue a hillsborough inquiry ?
burnham says a decision was taken not to pursue this , even though documents emerged pointing to a policy cover-up .
that was a major injustice .
q : what would your advice be to labour mps who say they definitely want to vote against the bill next week ?
burnham says he would advise mps to wait for the party 's decision .
he does not advocate breaking collective decisions .
q : did you discuss the two-child benefits limit with rachel reeves [ the shadow work and pensions secretary and a key burnham supporter ] ?
burnham says he has discussed this with all members of his team .
he will not go into details , he says .
he says a national living wage should cover all people , not just over-25s .
q : did shadow cabinet today over-turn harriet harman 's position on the welfare bill ?
will labour vote with the snp against the bill next week ?
burnham says he made his own position clear .
labour is voting against the budget tonight , citing four reasons .
three of those elements are in the welfare bill .
he says he will wait to see what harman decides on the bill .
burnham says westminster has shirked the problem of addressing the problem of care for the elderly for far too long .
labour will win again when it has the courage to speak for everyone , and provide an answer .
the party that comes up with that answer will be rewarded by the electorate , he says .
q : would you , as labour leader , continue to support hs2 ?
burnham says east/west transport links are a higher priority .
q : how will you vote on the welfare bill ?
burnham says the party has not taken a view yet .
but he set out his view at shadow cabinet .
labour should table a reasoned amendment .
but , if that fails , it should vote against .
there are two main reasons , he says .
it would weaken work incentives ; and it gets rid of child poverty measurements .
q : [ from the sun ] can you commit to being interviewed by the sun before the contest is over ?
burnham says , as leader , he would talk to all papers .
but he wo n't commit to giving an interview to the sun before 12 september .
he thinks the last labour government got too close to the press .
q : do you think that one reason for the failure to hold a hilsborough inquiry was reluctance to upset news international ?
burnham says he does not know all the reasons why labour did not order an inquiry .
but , when he raised the issue , he was told to let the matter drop .
q : how are you different from ed miliband ?
wo n't the tories be pleased to have you as leader ?
burnham says the tories speak with forked tongue '' on this .
there is an element of double bluff going on .
a poll of tories at the weekend found they did not want him or yvette cooper .
q : do you regret your support for id cards ?
no , says burnham .
he thinks identifying who you are is part of life .
the argument made then was valid , and remains people .
government needs to help people assert and protect their identity .
but that does not mean he wants to bring back id cards , he says .
q : last time you came fourth .
now you are favourite .
what has changed ?
burnham says last time he thought david miliband would stand , and ed balls , and that there was space for someone to come through the middle .
that happened .
but he did not expect ed miliband to stand .
standing for the leadership is a very good thing for politicians to do , he says .
it forces people to speak for themselves .
he says labour has to change .
it has to reaffirm its emotional bond with people .
q : would you give jeremy corbyn a shadow cabinet role ?
does he want one , burnham asks .
he says he is not giving thought to those issues .
but corbyn is a thoroughly decent man '' .
his presence has enhanced the debate , he says .

documents.title: burnham 's q & a
text: burnham is now taking questions .
q : would you ever contemplate exit from the eu ?
no , says burnham .
support for the eu should be part of what it means to be labour : collectivist and internationalist .
but that is not to say that there should not be big changes to the eu .
he says he was the first in the labour contest to say the referendum should be brought forward .
he thinks it should take place next autumn .
and he called for a separate labour campaign .
he says he wants to increase labour protections .
brussels has not given enough attention to communities affected by mass migration , he says .
those communities need extra help .
they often feel they are not getting it .
countries should be able to use unspent structural funding to help areas most affected by mass migration .
freedom to work , yes , he says .
freedom to claim , no .
he says pro-europeans will not win over the public if people think the contributory principle is being undermined .
burnham winds up by saying he wants to supply something in short supply - hope .
and he ends with a joke about his sign-off to his letters to prince charles .

documents.title: burnham says labour should vote against the welfare bill as it stands
text: burnham turns to the welfare bill .
he has been through it in great detail , he says .
it is unsupportable '' because it does not do what it says on the tin '' .
it wo n't encourage people into work ; indeed , it might do the opposite .
and it contains some punitive measures on child poverty .
the public are in favour of welfare reform , as am i '' .
but , he says , this will punish measures .
he says he told the shadow cabinet this morning that labour should table a reasoned amendment to the bill .
there are some good aspects in the bill , he says .
he says he could support a welfare cap , with certain changes .
but , if the reasoned amendment fails , labour should oppose the bill , he says .
he stresses that this does not mean he is against welfare reform .
he will give a speech on this tomorrow .
he would bring down the housing benefit bill by building more houses .
and he favours tax breaks for people who pay the living wage to people of all ages .
burnham says labour should vote against the welfare bill as it stands .
burnham says the leadership contest has been good-natured on the whole , but nevertheless things have been said .
one was that candidates have to have children .
that is absolute nonsense '' .
there is also the treasury 's two-child test .
he has failed that , he says .
more seriously , he says the budget was deeply political and divisive '' .
what we have is a chancellor playing politics with the lives of the vulnerable , he says .
it was about political positioning '' .
george osborne quite liked the labour manifesto ; he took some ideas from it .
but how can he justify limiting the national minimum wage '' to the over-25s .
it can not be truly national on that basis .
that will create a two-tier workforce .
that will fuel the alienation of young people , he says .

documents.title: andy burnham 's speech
text: andy burnham is speaking now .
he says he will play in the labour v the lobby football match if elected leader .
but he has lost his strike partner , ed balls .
but he may have a replacement , dan jarvis .
and he has a message for anyone from the sun playing ; bring your shin pads .
robert hutton , the bloomberg political editor , has just introduced andy burnham .
he told him he was at the very centre of the place he most hates , the westminster bubble .

documents.title: andy burnham 's press gallery hustings
text: andy burnham is due to speak at a labour leadership hustings at the commons press gallery .
it should start in about 10 minutes .
i 'll be covering it in detail .

documents.title: cameron appears to rule out beefing up evel plans in light of snp 's hunting stance
text: and this is what david cameron said about the hunting decision when he was taking questions after his gender equality speech .
cameron accused the snp of being opportunistic '' .
asked if he had been outfoxed '' by nicola sturgeon , he replied : i would not quite put it like that .
the position of the snp has up to now always been clear which is that they do not vote on matters that are purely of interest to england or england and wales .
i find their position entirely opportunistic and very hard to explain in any other way .
he appeared to rule out strengthening the english votes for english laws ( evel ) plans to stop scottish mps voting on hunting .
such a move would take britain towards a federal solution , he said .
asked if he would beef up the current evel plans in the light of the snp 's move , he replied : i am a believer in the united kingdom .
i want us to stay together as a united kingdom and we have to recognise that england is a very large part of the total .
you are never going to get total perfection .
if you want total perfection in terms of english votes for english laws you would have to have an english parliament , a federal system .
that is not what we are proposing .
what we are proposing is relatively modest , it really is that you should not be able to legislate in the united kingdom parliament against the wishes of english mps .
it 's a veto , a block , rather than a right of initiative .
i think that is right .
david cameron leaving number 10 today .
shutterstock
here are the main points from the number 10 lobby briefing relating to hunting and english votes for english laws ( evel ) .
downing street said david cameron was disappointed '' that the snp had decided to vote on the hunting act .
this was was an issue that does not involve the scottish people '' and one where the snp had previously said it would not vote , the prime minister 's spokeswoman said .

she said that the snp 's decision explained why the government had decided not to go ahead with tomorrow 's vote , although she stopped short of saying explicitly that the government pulled the vote because it knew it was going to lose .

the spokeswoman implicitly accused the snp of hypocrisy , saying that they were refusing to accept the view that something that is fine for scotland '' ( ie , a law that allows more than two dogs to be used to flush out a fox for it to be shot ) should also be acceptable for england and wales .
downing street confirmed that the government 's current plan for english votes for english laws ( evel ) would not stop all mps having a vote on the proposal to relax the hunting ban .

the spokeswoman said that the revised plans for evel published today ( see 11.58am ) contained a new paragraph making it clear that all mps would continue to vote on estimates ( the allocation of money to government departments ) .
this was implicit in the original plans , but the new paragraph makes this clearer .
she implied that in other respects the plans have not changed .
number 10 refused to firmly commit itself to holding a vote on the proposal to relax the hunting ban in the future .
asked if the vote scheduled to take place tomorrow would definitely take place in the future , the spokeswoman just said the government would set out its decision on the next steps in due course '' .
but she said cameron was still committed to his manifesto commitment ( which was for something different - a free vote on the repeal of the hunting act ) .
the spokeswoman played down suggestions that the government might try to beef up its evel plans to stop scottish mps voting on hunting .
asked about this , she said cameron 's approach has been to stop scottish mps being able to impose laws that only affect england without the consent of [ english mps ] .
there will be a debate tomorrow , and an opportunity for a further debate in the autumn .
asked what the government would do if tory mps tried to amend the plans so that they stop scottish mps voting on england-only matters , she dismissed that as hypothetical .
the government has just published its revised proposals for english votes for english laws ( pdf ) .
i 'm just off to the number 10 lobby briefing .
i 'll post again after 12.30pm .
angus robertson , the snp 's leader at westminster , has put out a statement about the government 's decision to pull the vote on hunting .
he says this is the fourth issue on which the snp has forced the government to back down .

this is the fourth issue where the snp group have led the opposition in forcing the tories into backing down - stopping the eu referendum being on the same day as the scottish parliament election , getting any moves to repeal the human rights act kicked into the long grass , the debacle of the government having to abandon last week 's vote on english votes for english laws , and now stopping this week 's vote to relax the fox hunting ban in england and wales .
this is another powerful reminder of just how fragile the tories ' majority is - on these four issues it was non-existent , they were staring defeat in the face , and there will be more such issues .
he also urged the government to talk to the snp about english votes for english laws .

and on the issue of evel , the uk government should respond positively to the first minister 's letter and agree to sensible discussions on the basis of mutual respect - rather than laying down the law to make scotland 's representation at westminster second class .
and he urged labour to vote with the snp against the welfare bill next week .
the snp group are delivering on our pledge to help deliver progressive politics across the uk .

we were fully prepared to vote with labour to stop harm being done to foxes in england and wales - labour should now commit to voting with the snp next week against harm being done to people by the tories ' cruel welfare cuts .
on the subject of evel , it is not clear what compromise ( if any ? )
the snp might propose in sensible discussions '' with the government .
i 've called the snp to ask for some guidance on this , but no one was available now to help .
outside westminster the anti-hunting protesters have blocked a road , the bbc 's james landale reports .
james landale ( @ bbcjlandale ) anti hunt protestors block road outside commons .
here is some twitter comment from journalists on the hunting decision .
from the guardian 's owen jones owen jones ( @ owenjones84 ) the tories to bring forward undermining the constitution and the union so they can start bringing back fox hunting .
british politics , 2015 .
from the telegraph 's christopher hope christopher hope ( @ christopherhope ) so far david cameron has performed three u-turns under pressure from mps ( evel , eu ref and now fox hunting ) .
his government is 67 days old .

from the birmingham post 's jonathan walker jonathan walker ( @ jonwalker121 ) media trying to decide whether pulling the foxhunting vote is a humiliation for cameron or the snp doing him a big favour
this is from joe anderson , the labour mayor of liverpool , on the hunting decision .
joe anderson ( @ joeforliverpool ) let 's use the commons time freed up with the arrogant cancelation of fox hunting debate , to debate the attacks on the working poor in budget
this is interesting .
it shows where support for the hunting act is strongest and weakest .
yougov ( @ yougov ) every region of britain supports the fox hunting ban -
caroline lucas , the green mp , has tweeted a of herself , with some of the anti-hunting protesters .
caroline lucas ( @ carolinelucas ) great turnout to celebrate a win today as cameron backs down on efforts to undermine the ban # keeptheban
here 's the guardian 's story on the shelving of the vote on hunting .
this is from the new statesman 's george eaton .
george eaton ( @ georgeeaton ) tories have now pulled votes on fox hunting , evel and human rights act - proof that a majority of 12 is barely a majority at all .
animal rights activists have been campaigning in westminster today against the plans to relax the ban on hunting .
paul waugh ( @ paulwaugh ) just broke the news to the foxes that the govt has shelved the vote .
they were n't quite sure how to react .
paul waugh ( @ paulwaugh ) latest foxhunting protestors .
`` we will , we will , we will stop you ! ''
was the chant .
nod to @ twitterid i reckon .

michael deacon ( @ michaelpdeacon ) a spokesman for the vulpine community jon scammell ( @ jonscammell ) protesters say no to # foxhunting @ twitterid @ twitterid @ twitterid @ twitterid @ twitterid @ twitterid
here is some reaction from mps to the news that the hunting vote has been pulled .

from the snp 's stewart mcdonald stewart mcdonald mp ( @ stewartmcdonald ) be in no doubt , the tories are on the run thanks to @ twitterid # foxhunting from labour 's jonathan ashworth jonathan ashworth mp ( @ jonashworth ) cameron warned of chaos , that 's exactly what he 's got .
with 24 hours to go he 's had to pull fox hunting vote .
what a shambles from labour 's diane abbott diane abbott ( @ hackneyabbott ) tories abandon vote on fox hunting .

congratulations to anti-blood sports campaigners everywhere # keeptheban from chris bryant , the shadow culture secretary chris bryant mp ( @ rhonddabryant ) incidentally i do n't think the tories will win a vote on # keeptheban even when they 've rigged the vote .
from labour 's richard burden richard burden mp ( @ richardburdenmp ) government has pulled tomorrow 's hunting vote .
seems they did not want to risk parliament making up its own mind in the - er - `` free vote ''
the government was due to publish revised plans for english votes for english laws ahead of tomorrow 's debate .
but they still have not emerged .

faisal islam ( @ faisalislam ) still no sign of the \governments revised evel plans , due yesterday , due to be debated tomorrow as my colleague rowena mason points out , the current plans for english votes for english laws ( which are summarised here - pdf ) would not allow the relaxation of the hunting ban to get through , with the snp voting against .

rowena mason ( @ rowenamason ) i do n't see how evel will help tory leadership pass foxhunting change apart from indicating how english and welsh mps feel -needs double maj that is because the plans ( which cover secondary legislation , as well as primary legislation ) give english mps a veto on legislation ; they can stop the commons as a whole imposing legislation on england that a majority of english mps oppose .
they do not allow english mps to push legislation through against the wishes of the commons as a whole .
but perhaps a rethink is going on .
nicola sturgeon , the snp leader and scotland 's first minister , has welcomed the government 's decision to pull the hunting vote .
tim reid ( @ timreidbbc ) sturgeon : '' i 'm glad they have pulled the vote . ''
but says `` the reason he ca n't carry his own parliamentary group '' # foxhunting
labour claims the hunting decision is a shambles '' .
this is from the official labour whips account .
labour whips ( @ labourwhips ) absolute shambles from pm & govt on fox hunting , schedulde at shortest poss .
notice backdoor attempt to repeal & now appear to have pulled
ministers plan to hold the hunting vote after english votes for english laws has been implemented , my colleague patrick wintour reports .
patrick wintour ( @ patrickwintour ) government has withdrawn fox hunting vote fearing defeat .
issue to be revisited in autumn when rules on scottish mps voting changed .
one consequence of the government 's decision to pull the hunting vote is that mps will have more time tomorrow to debate english votes for english laws .

documents.title: government pulls the vote on foxhunting
text: the government has pulled tomorrow 's planned voting on foxhunting , the bbc is reporting .
following the snp 's decision to take part , it was almost inevitable that the proposals , which would relax the hunting ban , would be defeated , and so this is perhaps not a big surprise .

documents.title: carney says rescuing greece will require herculean efforts ''
text: the hearing is starting .
andrew tyrie , the committee chair , starts .
q : can greece recover at current exchange rates ?
mark carney says the statement by euro-group leaders yesterday is designed to enable that to happen .
but what is in that statement requires herculean efforts '' from all sides .
q : can hercules pull it off ?
it will be tested .
jack blanchard ( @ jack blanchard ) mark carney : greek crisis underlines the `` institutional shortcomings '' of the eurozone this is still unfinished business , he says .
carney says rescuing greece will require herculean efforts '' from greece and eurozone countries .

documents.title: mark carney gives evidence to commons treasury committee
text: mark carney , the governor of the bank of england , is about to give evidence to the commons treasury committee .
my colleague jill treanor wrote a preview story yesterday .
here 's how it starts .

the bank of england governor , mark carney , will face questions this week about the outlook for interest rates and the precarious situation in greece when he becomes the first witness to appear before the new-look treasury select committee .

the parliamentary committee - one of the most influential in westminster - will meet on tuesday for the first time since the general election , the first opportunity for the new members to set out their agendas .
the conservative mp andrew tyrie remains its chairman after his reappointment was unopposed .
he will be rejoined by fellow tory mps mark garnier and steve baker along with labour mp john mann .
reflecting the shape of the new parliament , the newly elected scottish national party mp george kerevan will question witnesses for the first time .
labour mps wes streeting , bill esterson and helen goodman have also been elected to the committee alongside the conservatives jacob rees-mogg and chris philp .

documents.title: snp 's hunting decision - reaction and analysis
text: tomorrow mps are due to spend 90 minutes debating a statutory instrument relaxing the hunting ban and , separately , the matter of english votes for english laws ( evel ) .
following the snp 's decision yesterday to vote on the hunting act , even though it does not affect scotland , those two issues have effectively been merged .
a week ago , when mps last debated evel ( it 's becoming a weekly occurrence ) , it was clear that david cameron was facing a significant backlash from backbenchers .
the threat of a revolt was so serious that ministers had to put off the vote until the autumn .
but now , in the light of the snp decision , which could see scottish mps having a decisive impact on an england-only matter , the tory evel rebellion may well evaporate .
here are some examples of what conservative mps have been saying .
from sir peter bottomley the scottish national party risk making themselves look foolish , unprincipled and unwise by voting against making english law similar to scottish law .
this action is naive - it makes them look silly and is perhaps the first major mis-step by nicola sturgeon .
from nick boles nick boles ( @ nickbolesmp ) whatever your views on hunting it 's surely a bit rich of snp to vote to deny england a law that scotland already has .

time for evel methinks from nick de bois nick de bois ( @ nickdebois ) fox hunting vote tomorrow is set to become more about english votes 4 english laws than hunting as snp wade in to vote on an english matter from grant shapps grant shapps ( @ grantshapps ) now i 'm no fan of fox hunting , but snp preparing to vote on this english & wales only issue shows why english votes for english laws needed !
nicola sturgeon must know that the snp 's decision to vote on hunting will only increase the chances of the conservatives pushing their evel measures through the commons .

david cameron claims boosting the voting rights of english mps could strengthen the union , but sturgeon has said it will have the opposite effect and her analysis seems more plausible than the prime minister 's ( not least because she is in a position to make it self-fulfilling ) .

overall , as the labour mp chris bryant says ( conveniently forgetting that labour collaborated with the snp on this - see 9.32am ) this is an episode that leaves the union looking even more creaky than it did 24 hours ago .
chris bryant mp ( @ rhonddabryant ) seems tory mps and snp on mutually assured course to dismantle the union .
update : alex massie has come to much the same conclusion in a blog for coffee house .
here 's an extract .
but it does leave one wondering if the snp 's full-throated opposition to the government 's shambolic-but-hardly-revolutionary proposals for evel waswholly sincere .
because this kind of fox-hunting ploy is the kind of thing designed to infuriate english tory mps .
and so resentment is stoked , grievances nursed , and outrage manufactured on both sides of the border .
job done .
if nothing else , you might at least admire the party 's opportunism .
here are comments from two journalists on the snp 's decision to vote on english hunting legislation .
from the independent on sunday 's jane merrick jane merrick ( @ janemerrick23 ) remember when david cameron warned that voting labour would allow the snp to block legislation + cause chaos ?
thank god that 's not happening from total politics ' david singleton david singleton ( @ singersz ) snp set to thwart cameron 's moves to relax the hunting ban in england .
it could be a blessing in disguise for tories
a survation poll today suggests the snp are on course to increase the size of their majority at holyrood in next year 's election .

gerry hassan ( @ gerryhassan ) survation poll seat prediction : snp 71 lab 24 con 14 green 12 ldem 7 ukip 1 # sp16 alan roden ( @ alanroden ) scottish daily mail : new poll shows snp is heading for landslide victory , but scots still do n't want independence .

documents.title: cpi inflation fell to zero in june
text: inflation was zero last month on the government 's preferred measure , according to the office for national statistics .
consumer price index ( cpi ) inflation fell to 0 % in june , from 0.1 % in may , the ons says .
retail price index ( rpi ) inflation was 1 % in june , unchanged from may .
here is the ons news release .
and here is the ons statistical bulletin , with the full details ( pdf ) .
labour formally asked the snp to vote against the proposal to relax the hunting ban .
in an article for huffington post , paul nuttall , the ukip deputy leaders , says this shows that labour was lying during the election campaign when it said it would not give the snp any influence .
here 's an extract .
in the run up to the last general election , a huge play was made about the risk a labour government would effectively mean an snp government .
miliband tried to reassure us non-scots that if we trusted him with the reins of the uk , labour would not allow the snp influence they did n't deserve .
the public did n't believe him , and the public as it turns out , were absolutely right .

whether you are a tree-hugging , organic falafel eating vegan , a blood thirsty rampaging toff who wants to rip foxes apart , or somewhere in between , you probably , like me , hope that there is fairness in the mechanism of how laws are made in the country it was a crucially important announcement when labour assured voters labour would not go into coalition or do a deal with the snp , but their recent letter to sturgeon on the matter of the fox hunting bill prove they were lying .
paul nuttall thomond for the guardian
ian murray , the shadow scottish secretary , told the today programme that he was glad the snp had decided to vote against the plan to relax the hunting ban .
but if the tories lost , it would not be the snp 's fault , he said .
the conservatives have a majority of 12 .
they could win this vote tomorrow , if they so wished to do so .
the fact that they 're not is because they have their own backbench rebellion going on .
here is more from what liam fox , the conservative former defence secretary , said on the today programme about the snp 's decision to take part in the vote on foxhunting in england .
people in england are perfectly capable of electing mps to look after their own interests , so we can thank nicola sturgeon to keep her nose out of that one .
in february she was saying that hunting is the sort of issue she would not want snp members of parliament voting on because it purely affects england .
so what we 've seen really is a pretty toxic mixture of opportunism and hypocrisy coming from the snp .
he also said that the snp was sticking two fingers up '' at the government over english votes for english laws .

and it is particularly galling because the government has been very careful , and parliament has been very careful , to try and protect the union by moving slowly and thoughtfully and constructively in terms of english votes on english laws .
and more time has been given to the debate .
and it seems that while we 're trying to be reasonable to the snp , they are sticking two fingers up at us .
liam fox ghazzal/rex

documents.title: sturgeon defends snp 's u-turn decision on hunting vote
text: in february nicola sturgeon , the snp leader and scottish first minister , said the snp would not vote on issues just affecting england , like hunting .
the snp have a longstanding position of not voting on matters that purely affect england - such as foxhunting south of the border , for example - and we stand by that .

last night , in a move that makes it almost certain that david cameron 's attempt to relax the hunting ban in england and wales will fail , the snp announced that they had changed their stance , and that their mps would vote on this matter tomorrow .
sturgeon was on the today programme earlier and was asked to justify this .
to her credit , she did not try to pretend it was anything other than a u-turn .
she admitted that she had changed her mind , and she said there were three reasons why .
firstly , there has been overwhelming demand from people in england for the snp to vote on this issue this week .

i ca n't think of another issue where i 've had more communication and it 's unprecedented for so much of that to come from england and what people have been saying to me is if what you meant during the election that you cared about more than scotland , you wanted to hold out a hand of friendship to people in england , build progressive alliances where you could , if you meant that , then please on this issue vote with us to retain the ban on foxhunting .

the second reason is that actually this debate over the past debate has thrown a spotlight onto scotland 's foxhunting law because what the conservative government are saying is they 're simply bringing the english law into line with the scottish law - that 's made a lot of people in scotland think 'should n't we be tightening up our law to bring it into line with english law as it stands ' .

inevitably there will now be a look at the scottish law and what we will be looking at is whether the current english law is better and actually there is an interest for us , then , in making sure the english law stays as it is .
the third reason is perhaps less to do with foxhunting .
since the election , david cameron 's government has shown very little respect to the mandate that scottish mps have .
on the scotland bill , reasonable amendments backed by the overwhelming majority of scottish mps have been voted down .
the english votes for english laws proposals brought forward go beyond any reasonable proposition and look to make scottish mps effectively second-class citizens in the house of commons .

so , i think if there 's an opportunity - as there appears to be here - and on an issue where david cameron appears to be out of touch with majority english opinion as well , to actually remind the government how slender their majority is .
i 've taken the quote from politicshome .
on the today programme liam fox , the conservative former defence secretary , has just said the snp move amounts to a toxic mixture of opportunism and hypocrisy '' .
i will post more from his interview , and other reaction to the snp move , soon .
otherwise , it is set to be a busy day at westminster .
here is the agenda .
9.30am : inflation figures for june are published .

9.30am : lord owen , the former sdp leader , and jack straw , the labour former foreign secretary , give evidence to the public administration and constitutional affairs committee about the purdah rules and referendums .
10.15am : mark carney , the governor of the bank of england , gives evidence to the commons treasury committee .
12pm : david cameron gives a speech on gender equality in the workplace .
12.30pm : theresa may , the home secretary , gives a statement to the commons on the immigrant crisis at calais .
1.30pm : andy burnham takes part in a commons press gallery labour leadership q & a .
2.45pm : natacha bouchart , the mayor of calais , james brokenshire , the immigration minister , and others give evidence to the commons home affairs committee about the situation at calais .
as usual i will be covering the breaking political news as it happens , as well as bringing you the best reaction , comment and analysis from the web .
i will post a summary at lunchtime and another in the afternoon .
if you want to follow me on twitter , i 'm on @ twitterid
